Award.AwardTitle: BRUCE and ROSA go to Coney Island - interactive robotic fish join the New York Aquarium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This CRPA award will engage public audiences in a robotic experience that will help them better understand live fish, aquatic environments, engineering and marine science. The issue addressed by this project deals with enhancing the aquarium experience and learning several new concepts in biology and animal behavior. Each engaged youngster can control a robot fish or even a school of fish to experiment with how fish function and perhaps to mimic what he or she has observed in the big tank of live fish. One special App that is downloadable to i-devices allows the viewer to see what the fish sees and can control that fish.

This activity is an aquarium exhibit containing robotic fish. It is engineered so that external devices can keep the fish energized, but the key is that observers can actually control the movements of the fish remotely using the exhibit controls or their own i-device such as an i-Phone. This exhibit will be at the New York aquarium on the Boardwalk of Brooklyn where large numbers of people visit. Many of these individuals are from under-served groups.

This is a cooperative venture between Polytechnic University of New York, New York University and the New York Aquarium.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have demonstrated the use of an interactive robotic fish exhibit as a tool in informal science learning settings to promote learning in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). We have created a novel framework for BRUCE (Bioinspired Robotic Underwater Carangiform Exhibit) featuring a shoal of ROSAs (Remotely Operated Swimming Avatars), which culminated in the Commodore prototype.

We have examined the enjoyment and usability of Commodore by systematically varying the degree of interactivity of its controller. We specifically considered an iDevice app with various modalities varying in the level of robot autonomy offered, a natural user interface with the feature to collect sensory data through hand gestures, and a traditional joystick controller. We have studied visitors’ responses to the exhibit at informal science learning settings in with exit surveys and through open-ended feedback comments. We have quantitatively examined the deployment of the exhibit at informal science learning venues, by measuring visitor knowledge, perception of STEM, physical and intellectual engagement, and learning. The analysis leveraged implicit and explicit analysis tools, such as a post experience survey, internal data collection, heat maps, and behavior coding.

From an engineering perspective, we have studied the influence of tail beat amplitude, tail beat frequency, and wave number on the swimming speed of the robotic fish and analyzed its performance in waypoint path following. In an effort to automate the exhibit, we have created an autonomous charging system for the robotics fish through direct contact and theoretically studied its charging and discharging processes. The project also contributed to an improved understanding of educational applications in the assessment of exhibits, scaling laws for robotic fish prototypes, and fabrication methods for robotic fish prototypes utilizing recent advancements in smart materials and multi-material 3D printing.

Several graduate and undergraduate students have received training in interdisciplinary research across the field of informal science learning and underwater robotics, publishing their findings in international journals and presenting at technical conferences. Also, high school teachers have been involved in hands-on experimental research, across informal science education and underwater robotics. Research findings have been heavily disseminated to the general public through numerous outreach events across United States (including New York City, Washington DC, Jersey City, and Minneapolis), in which participants interacted with robotic fish and were introduced to exciting and important STEM concepts related to the robotics, biology, and environmental science.
